title: Matthew Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Matthew chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Matthew Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Matthew Chapter 7.

questions.question: What does Matthew 7:1 command us not to do?
questions.correctAnswer: Judge not
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:1 says, 'Judge not, that ye be not judged,' instructing against judging others.

questions.question: According to Matthew 7:3, what is the 'mote' that one sees in another?
options: A speck in the brother's eye
questions.correctAnswer: A speck in the brother's eye
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:3 refers to the 'mote' as a speck in a brother's eye, contrasting it with the beam in one's own eye.

questions.question: What should one do first before helping a brother with the mote in his eye, according to Matthew 7:5?
options: Cast out the beam from your own eye
questions.correctAnswer: Cast out the beam from your own eye
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:5 instructs to 'first cast out the beam out of thine own eye' before helping others.

questions.question: In Matthew 7:6, what are we advised not to give to dogs or swine?
options: That which is holy and pearls
questions.correctAnswer: That which is holy and pearls
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:6 tells us not to give 'that which is holy unto the dogs' nor cast 'pearls before swine.'

questions.question: What will happen if you ask, seek, and knock, according to Matthew 7:7?
options: It shall be given, found, and opened to you
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be given, found, and opened to you
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:7 promises that asking, seeking, and knocking will result in receiving, finding, and doors opening.

questions.question: According to Matthew 7:9, what would a man not give his son if he asked for bread?
questions.correctAnswer: A stone
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:9 says that a man would not give his son a stone if he asked for bread.

questions.question: What is described as 'the law and the prophets' in Matthew 7:12?
options: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you
questions.correctAnswer: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:12 calls the Golden Rule 'the law and the prophets.'

questions.question: Which gate is described as 'strait' and leading to life in Matthew 7:14?
questions.correctAnswer: The narrow gate
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:14 describes the strait gate as narrow and leading unto life.

questions.question: Who are false prophets compared to in Matthew 7:15?
questions.correctAnswer: Ravening wolves in sheep's clothing
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:15 warns that false prophets come in sheep's clothing but are inwardly ravening wolves.

questions.question: How can you know false prophets, according to Matthew 7:16?
questions.correctAnswer: By their fruits
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:16 states you shall know them by their fruits.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 7:21 states that everyone who calls Jesus 'Lord' will enter the kingdom of heaven.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:21 says not everyone who calls Jesus 'Lord' will enter, but only those who do the will of the Father.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 7:22, some will claim to have prophesied and done wonders in Jesus’ name.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:22 records many claiming to have prophesied and done wonders in Jesus’ name.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 7:29 says Jesus taught as one having authority, unlike the scribes.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:29 states Jesus taught with authority, not like the scribes.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Matthew 7:24: 'Therefore whosoever heareth these sayings of mine, and doeth them, I will liken him unto a wise man, which built his house upon a ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: rock
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:24 compares the wise man to one who built his house upon a rock.

questions.question: What happens to the house built on sand, according to Matthew 7:27?
options: It falls with a great fall
questions.correctAnswer: It falls with a great fall
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:27 says the house built on sand fell and the fall was great.

medium.title: Matthew Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Matthew Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Matthew 7 teach us about humility when correcting others?
options: First address your own faults before helping others with theirs
Point out others' faults more than your own
Correct others publicly to shame them
questions.correctAnswer: First address your own faults before helping others with theirs
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:3-5 explains the importance of recognizing and removing one's own faults ('beam') before helping a brother with a smaller fault ('mote'), teaching humility and self-examination.

questions.question: According to Matthew 7, what principle guides how we should treat others?
options: Do to others as you would have them do to you
Judge others by their worst actions
Avoid all interactions to prevent conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Do to others as you would have them do to you
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:12 teaches the Golden Rule, emphasizing the importance of treating others with the kindness and respect we desire, summarizing the law and the prophets.

questions.question: A believer struggles with persistent unanswered prayers. Based on Matthew 7, what biblical truth encourages persistence in prayer?
options: Ask, seek, and knock, and it will be given or opened to you
Prayers are only answered once a year
Only certain people can have prayers answered
questions.correctAnswer: Ask, seek, and knock, and it will be given or opened to you
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:7-8 assures that those who ask, seek, and knock will receive, find, and have doors opened, encouraging persistence and faith in prayer.

questions.question: How does Matthew 7 instruct us about discernment in sharing valuable spiritual truths?
options: Do not give holy things to dogs or cast pearls before swine
Keep spiritual truths secret from all
questions.correctAnswer: Do not give holy things to dogs or cast pearls before swine
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:6 warns believers to exercise wisdom in sharing sacred truths, avoiding those who would disrespect or harm the message.

questions.question: What does Matthew 7 say about the gate and way leading to life versus destruction?
options: The gate is narrow and the way is difficult leading to life; the gate is wide and way broad leading to destruction
Both gates are wide and lead to life
The gate to life is broad and easy
Few find the gate to destruction
questions.correctAnswer: The gate is narrow and the way is difficult leading to life; the gate is wide and way broad leading to destruction
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:13-14 contrasts the narrow gate and difficult way that leads to life with the wide gate and broad way that leads to destruction, indicating few find the right path.

questions.question: A church leader wants to ensure true teaching. What guidance does Matthew 7 provide about recognizing false prophets?
options: You will know them by their fruits
Believe all who speak in Jesus' name
questions.correctAnswer: You will know them by their fruits
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:15-20 teaches that false prophets may appear harmless but are recognized by their bad fruits, while true teachers produce good fruits.

questions.question: How does Matthew 7 describe the security of those who obey Jesus’ teachings?
options: They are like a wise man who built his house on the rock
They are like a man building on sand
questions.correctAnswer: They are like a wise man who built his house on the rock
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:24-25 compares those who hear and do Jesus’ words to a wise man who builds on rock, able to withstand storms, symbolizing stability through obedience.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 7, many who claim to do works in Jesus’ name will enter the kingdom of heaven.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:21-23 explains that not everyone who calls Jesus 'Lord' or performs works in His name will enter the kingdom, but only those who do the Father's will.

questions.question: A believer is judging another harshly for a minor fault. Based on Matthew 7, what biblical principle applies here?
options: Judge not, lest you be judged
questions.correctAnswer: Judge not, lest you be judged
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:1-2 teaches that judging others harshly invites judgment upon oneself and warns to be cautious and humble in judging.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Therefore everyone who hears these words of mine and _______ them will be like a wise man who built his house on the rock."
questions.correctAnswer: does
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:24 states that those who hear and do Jesus' sayings are likened to the wise man who built his house on the rock, emphasizing obedience.

questions.question: What does Matthew 7 say about the kind of gifts God gives to those who ask Him?
options: God gives good things to those who ask Him
God gives stones instead of bread
God gives serpents instead of fish
questions.correctAnswer: God gives good things to those who ask Him
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:9-11 illustrates that just as earthly parents give good gifts to their children, God, who is perfect, gives good things to those who ask Him.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 7 says that a corrupt tree can produce good fruit.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:18 clearly states a corrupt tree cannot bring forth good fruit, highlighting the connection between character and actions.

questions.question: According to Matthew 7, what happens to trees that do not bear good fruit?
options: They are cut down and thrown into the fire
questions.correctAnswer: They are cut down and thrown into the fire
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:19 says every tree not producing good fruit is hewn down and cast into the fire, symbolizing judgment for unfruitfulness.

questions.question: How does Matthew 7 describe Jesus’ teaching style compared to the scribes?
options: He taught with authority, not like the scribes
He taught with uncertainty and questions
He only repeated what scribes said
questions.correctAnswer: He taught with authority, not like the scribes
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:28-29 shows the people were astonished because Jesus taught as one with authority, contrasting the scribes' style.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to forgive a neighbor. Based on Matthew 7, what principle should encourage them?
options: Judge not, that ye be not judged
questions.correctAnswer: Judge not, that ye be not judged
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:1 teaches the principle of refraining from judgment to avoid being judged, encouraging forgiveness and humility in relationships.

hard.title: Matthew Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Matthew Chapter 7.

questions.question: In Matthew 7:3-5, Jesus uses the imagery of a 'mote' and a 'beam' in the eye. What literary device is primarily used here to convey the teaching on judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole
questions.explanation: The 'beam' in one's own eye versus a 'mote' in another's eye is an exaggerated comparison to emphasize the hypocrisy of judging others without self-examination, as shown in Matthew 7:3-5.

questions.question: Matthew 7:6 warns against giving 'that which is holy unto the dogs.' What cultural understanding from the ancient Near East helps clarify this metaphor?
options: Dogs were considered unclean and scavengers
Dogs were revered as sacred animals
Dogs were common pets in royal households
questions.correctAnswer: Dogs were considered unclean and scavengers
questions.explanation: In Jewish culture of the time, dogs were seen as unclean animals that scavenged refuse, making the metaphor a warning against giving sacred things to those who would not value them, as in Matthew 7:6.

questions.question: The phrase 'Ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you' (Matthew 7:7) is an example of what rhetorical device?
questions.correctAnswer: Tricolon
questions.explanation: The verse contains a tricolon, a series of three parallel commands that build intensity and reinforce the promise of receiving upon asking, seeking, and knocking, as per Matthew 7:7.

questions.question: How does Matthew 7:12, the 'Golden Rule,' function in the literary structure of this chapter?
options: It serves as a summary of the Law and the Prophets
It introduces the theme of false prophets
It concludes the teaching on judgment
It contrasts the narrow and wide gates
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a summary of the Law and the Prophets
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:12 encapsulates the ethical teachings of the entire Old Testament Law and Prophets, highlighting the importance of interpersonal conduct, as stated in the verse itself.

questions.question: According to Matthew 7:13-14, what typological contrast is presented between the 'strait gate' and the 'wide gate'?
options: Narrow gate symbolizes salvation; wide gate symbolizes destruction
Wide gate symbolizes salvation; narrow gate symbolizes destruction
Both gates lead to life but by different paths
Both gates represent different religious systems
questions.correctAnswer: Narrow gate symbolizes salvation; wide gate symbolizes destruction
questions.explanation: The strait (narrow) gate leads to life and few find it, while the wide gate leads to destruction and is the path many take, illustrating the contrast between salvation and perdition, Matthew 7:13-14.

questions.question: In the warning against false prophets (Matthew 7:15), what is the significance of 'sheep's clothing' and 'ravening wolves' in the original Greek and cultural context?
options: Sheep's clothing symbolizes innocence; wolves represent danger and deceit
Wolves are revered animals; sheep symbolize vulnerability
Sheep's clothing is a metaphor for wealth; wolves for poverty
The terms are randomly chosen animals without metaphorical meaning
questions.correctAnswer: Sheep's clothing symbolizes innocence; wolves represent danger and deceit
questions.explanation: In Jewish and Greco-Roman culture, wolves were known predators and sheep symbolized innocence and vulnerability, so false prophets disguise themselves as harmless but are dangerous, as in Matthew 7:15.

questions.question: The phrase 'Ye shall know them by their fruits' (Matthew 7:16) can be linked to which Old Testament imagery?
options: The creation of the world in Genesis 1
The exodus from Egypt in Exodus 12
questions.correctAnswer: The vineyard metaphor from Isaiah 5
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5 uses the vineyard and its fruit as a metaphor for Israel's faithfulness or unfaithfulness, paralleling the idea of judging prophets by their fruits in Matthew 7:16.

questions.question: What Greek word is translated as 'hypocrite' in Matthew 7:5, and what is its original theatrical meaning?
options: Hypokrites; an actor who wears a mask
questions.correctAnswer: Hypokrites; an actor who wears a mask
questions.explanation: The Greek word 'hypokrites' originally meant an actor on stage who wore a mask, implying someone who pretends or is insincere, as used in Matthew 7:5.

questions.question: Matthew 7:21-23 describes people who claim to do works in Jesus’ name but are rejected. What theological theme does this highlight that runs throughout the New Testament?
options: The necessity of doing the Father’s will beyond mere profession
The importance of performing miracles to enter heaven
The rejection of all miracles as signs
questions.correctAnswer: The necessity of doing the Father’s will beyond mere profession
questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes that verbal profession and works done in Jesus’ name are insufficient without doing the will of God, a theme consistent with New Testament teaching on faith and obedience.

questions.question: The metaphor of building a house on rock or sand in Matthew 7:24-27 serves what literary purpose?
options: It illustrates the stability of obedience versus the instability of disobedience
It symbolizes the difference between rich and poor
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates the stability of obedience versus the instability of disobedience
questions.explanation: The wise man builds on rock representing obedience to Jesus’ words, which withstands trials, while the foolish man builds on sand representing disobedience, resulting in collapse, Matthew 7:24-27.

questions.question: How does the teaching on judgment in Matthew 7:1-2 parallel the principle found in Leviticus 19:18?
options: Both warn against unfair or hypocritical judgment of others
Both command strict punishment for sinners
Both focus on ritual purity laws
Both prohibit all forms of judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Both warn against unfair or hypocritical judgment of others
questions.explanation: Leviticus 19:18 instructs not to bear grudges or seek revenge but to love others, paralleling Jesus’ teaching against hypocritical judgment in Matthew 7:1-2.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 7:11, the Father in heaven gives good gifts to those who ask Him, drawing a comparison to earthly fathers giving good gifts to their children.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:11 explicitly compares earthly fathers’ giving good gifts to their children to how much more God the Father will give good things to those who ask Him.

questions.question: In the context of Matthew 7:22-23, the phrase 'I never knew you' (Greek: 'ouk egnōka') signifies what kind of relationship between Jesus and those individuals?
options: A rejection due to lack of genuine relational knowledge
An acknowledgment of their prophetic gifts
A statement about ignorance of their names
questions.correctAnswer: A rejection due to lack of genuine relational knowledge
questions.explanation: The Greek verb 'ognōka' means intimate knowledge, so Jesus’ statement indicates a rejection based on the absence of true relationship despite external works, Matthew 7:23.

questions.question: Matthew 7:28-29 notes that the people were astonished because Jesus taught 'as one having authority, and not as the scribes.' What is the significance of this contrast in the historical context?
options: Jesus spoke with inherent authority rather than relying on tradition or citation
Jesus used more complicated language than scribes
Jesus performed miracles instead of teaching
The scribes were uneducated, unlike Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus spoke with inherent authority rather than relying on tradition or citation
questions.explanation: Unlike scribes who often cited other authorities, Jesus taught from His own authority, which amazed the listeners, as recorded in Matthew 7:28-29.

questions.question: Which theme in Matthew 7 foreshadows the judgment scene depicted in Revelation 20?
options: The separation of true and false followers based on their deeds
The call to enter through the narrow gate
The parable of the wise and foolish builders
questions.correctAnswer: The separation of true and false followers based on their deeds
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:21-23’s theme of being known by doing the will of the Father anticipates the final judgment scene in Revelation 20 where deeds determine eternal destiny.

theological.title: Matthew Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Matthew Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Matthew 7, what is the principle behind judging others as stated by Jesus?
options: You will be judged by the same standard you use
Judge others harshly to maintain righteousness
Only God can judge, so do not judge at all
questions.correctAnswer: You will be judged by the same standard you use
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:1-2 teaches that the judgment one gives will be the judgment one receives, highlighting the reciprocal nature of divine justice. This principle aligns with Leviticus 19:15 and James 2:13 which emphasize impartiality and mercy in judgment.

questions.question: In Matthew 7, what metaphor does Jesus use to illustrate hypocrisy in judging others?
options: A mote in your brother's eye and a beam in your own
questions.correctAnswer: A mote in your brother's eye and a beam in your own
questions.explanation: Verses 3-5 use the metaphor of noticing a small speck (mote) in another’s eye while ignoring a large beam in one’s own, illustrating the hypocrisy of judging others without self-examination. This resonates with Proverbs 21:2 and Romans 2:1 on self-righteous judgment.

questions.question: What warning does Jesus give in Matthew 7 about giving what is holy to dogs and casting pearls before swine?
options: It leads to harm and rejection
It is an act of generosity
It is a command to share everything
questions.correctAnswer: It leads to harm and rejection
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:6 warns not to give sacred things to those who will disrespect or harm them, symbolizing the danger of sharing the gospel with those who reject it. This echoes Proverbs 9:7-8 and Romans 16:17 about discerning whom to teach.

questions.question: What promise does Jesus make about asking, seeking, and knocking in Matthew 7?
options: Those who ask, seek, and knock will receive, find, and have doors opened
Only the righteous will receive answers
questions.correctAnswer: Those who ask, seek, and knock will receive, find, and have doors opened
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 promise that persistent prayer and seeking God’s will result in receiving blessings and revelation, reinforcing God’s readiness to respond as seen also in Jeremiah 29:13 and John 16:24.

questions.question: How does Jesus illustrate the goodness of God’s gifts in Matthew 7?
options: A father gives good gifts, not stones or snakes, to his children
God tests by giving evil gifts
God withholds good gifts until judgment
questions.correctAnswer: A father gives good gifts, not stones or snakes, to his children
questions.explanation: Verses 9-11 analogize God’s goodness to a father's care in giving good gifts, emphasizing God's benevolent nature, consistent with James 1:17 and Psalm 84:11.

questions.question: What is the summary of the law and the prophets according to Matthew 7?
options: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you
Love only those who love you
questions.correctAnswer: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you
questions.explanation: Matthew 7:12 encapsulates the ethical essence of the law and prophets in the Golden Rule, which is foundational in biblical ethics, also reflected in Leviticus 19:18 and Luke 6:31.

questions.question: According to Matthew 7, what characterizes the way that leads to destruction?
questions.correctAnswer: Wide gate and broad way
questions.explanation: Verse 13 describes the path to destruction as broad and accessible, contrasting with the narrow way to life, highlighting human tendency toward easy sinfulness. This theme is consistent with Deuteronomy 30:19 and Luke 13:24.

questions.question: How are false prophets described in Matthew 7?
options: Sheep in clothing but inwardly ravening wolves
questions.correctAnswer: Sheep in clothing but inwardly ravening wolves
questions.explanation: Verse 15 warns that false prophets appear harmless externally but are dangerous internally, a metaphor also used in Ezekiel 13:22 and Acts 20:29-30.

questions.question: How does Jesus say we can identify false prophets in Matthew 7?
questions.correctAnswer: By their fruits
questions.explanation: Verses 16-20 teach that the true nature of a prophet or person is revealed by their actions and outcomes (fruits), a principle echoed in Galatians 5:22-23 and John 15:2.

questions.question: According to Matthew 7, who will enter the kingdom of heaven?
options: Those who do the will of the Father in heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Those who do the will of the Father in heaven
questions.explanation: Verse 21 clarifies that verbal profession alone is insufficient; obedience to God’s will is essential for salvation, aligning with James 2:19-26 and 1 John 2:4.

questions.question: What reason does Jesus give in Matthew 7 for rejecting some who claim to have done mighty works in His name?
options: He never knew them because they practiced lawlessness
questions.correctAnswer: He never knew them because they practiced lawlessness
questions.explanation: Verse 23 reveals that despite impressive deeds, those who practice iniquity and lack a true relationship with Christ will be rejected, consistent with 1 Corinthians 13:2 and Matthew 25:41-46.

questions.question: In Matthew 7, what is the wise man compared to?
options: One who built his house upon a rock
One who built his house upon the sand
One who built his house on the sea
One who built his house in a forest
questions.correctAnswer: One who built his house upon a rock
questions.explanation: Verse 24 compares obedience to Jesus’ teachings to building a house on a solid rock foundation, symbolizing stability amid trials, similar to Psalm 18:2 and Isaiah 28:16.

questions.question: What happens to the house built on sand in Matthew 7?
options: It falls with a great crash when storms come
It becomes a place of refuge
questions.correctAnswer: It falls with a great crash when storms come
questions.explanation: Verses 26-27 describe the foolish man’s house collapsing under adverse conditions, illustrating the consequences of disobedience, consistent with Luke 6:47-49 and Proverbs 10:25.

questions.question: How did the people react after Jesus finished speaking in Matthew 7?
options: They were astonished at His teaching
questions.correctAnswer: They were astonished at His teaching
questions.explanation: Verse 28 records the crowd’s amazement, indicating the authority and uniqueness of Jesus’ doctrine, paralleling Luke 4:32 and John 7:46.

questions.question: How did Jesus teach according to Matthew 7?
questions.correctAnswer: With authority, unlike the scribes
questions.explanation: Verse 29 highlights Jesus’ unique authoritative teaching style, contrasting with the scribes’ traditional methods, consistent with Mark 1:22 and Luke 4:36.
